metadata.citation: Michael D. Young. 1996. “Cognitive Mapping Meets Semantic Networks.” The Journal of Conflict Resolution 40(3): 395-414.
metadata.annotation: Presents an enhanced cognitive mapping method using semantic networks to represent and analyze the belief structures underlying political decision making.

classification.summary: Represents beliefs as semantic networks (concepts and relationships), enabling deeper cognitive analysis through structural metrics and symbolic reasoning.

entities.name: Concept
entities.description: A basic node in the semantic network representing an idea or object in the belief structure.

entities.name: RelationshipNode
entities.description: A node that encodes an association (e.g., cause, is-a, action) between two or more concepts.

entities.name: ConjunctionNode
entities.description: A node that combines multiple concepts (subjects or objects) using 'and' or 'or.'

relationships.description: A relationship indicating equivalence or sameness of two concepts.
A relationship indicating a requirement or constraint under which something holds.
A relationship indicating a comparative preference among concepts.
A conditional relationship used to express hypothetical or contingent statements.
A relationship indicating ownership or possession of one concept by another.
Indicates a causal link that increases or furthers the object concept.
Indicates a causal link that decreases or hinders the object concept.
A class membership or categorical relationship (e.g., X is-a Y).
Used to express that a concept has a particular property or characteristic.
Indicates spatial relationship or placement of a concept.
Indicates that a particular relationship or action is a method or plan to achieve a goal.
A relationship indicating awareness or knowledge of one concept by another.
Justifies or provides grounds for another relationship or conclusion.
A relationship producing a direct effect on another concept.

conjunctions.description: A conjunction connecting multiple subjects or objects jointly.
A conjunction connecting alternative subjects or objects.

actions.description: An action signifying agreement to or receipt of something.
An action describing an emotional state or perception.
An action denoting the acquisition of something by payment.
An action granting permission or enabling another action.
An action showing respect or adherence to an obligation.
An action formally confirming or approving a proposal or agreement.
An action forcefully stating or declaring a viewpoint.
An action deliberately disregarding a concept or situation.
An action that decreases or lessens another concept.
An action providing help or support to a concept or entity.
An action exerting effect or sway on another concept.
An action freeing or making a concept available.
An aggressive action aimed at harming or subduing another concept.
An action involving entry into a situation to alter its course.
An action returning a concept to a previous or improved state.
An action forcibly entering another agent's territory or domain.
An action involving distribution or joint use with others.
An action denoting the deprivation or reduction of something previously possessed.
An action guiding or directing the behavior of others.
An action affixing a signature to endorse or finalize a document or agreement.
An action challenging or opposing another concept or actor.
An action restricting the extent or scope of something.
An action ceasing or preventing a concept or event.
An action deliberating or thinking about a concept or situation.
An action sustaining or preserving a state or relationship.
An action providing backing or assistance to another concept.
An action seeking advice or discussion with another actor or concept.
An action convening or coming together with others.
An action expressing an intention to inflict harm or punitive measures.
An action governing or overseeing the behavior of something.
An action observing or checking the progress of a concept.
An action employing or utilizing another concept for a purpose.
An action working together with another actor or concept.
An action discussing terms or reaching an agreement with others.
An action confirming or validating information or compliance.
An action making a choice or forming a resolution on a concept.
An action making something accessible or beginning a process.
An action traveling to or meeting another location or concept.
An action protecting or guarding against a threat.
An action instructing or commanding a concept or actor.
An action making an official decision by ballot or consensus.
An action postponing or deferring another concept or event.
An action arranging or structuring resources or actors toward a goal.
An action removing presence or participation from a situation.
An action compelling compliance or upholding a rule.
An action carrying out a task or role.
An action conceding or giving way to another concept.
An action increasing the value or level of a concept.
An action suggesting a plan or idea for consideration.

modifiers.description: Indicates that the relationship or action is set in a previous time.
Indicates that the relationship or action is ongoing or currently holds.
Indicates that the relationship or action is anticipated or projected to hold in a future time.
Indicates that the statement is desired to hold true; the actor’s aim or objective.
Indicates that the statement is conditional or potentially true given assumptions.
Indicates that the statement has an ideal or moral/ethical evaluation.

properties.name: truthValue
properties.description: Specifies the truth status a speaker attributes to a relationship (true, false, partial, possible, impossible).

properties.name: salience
properties.description: Indicates how frequently a relationship or concept is mentioned or used, implying relative strength.

metrics.name: Dependency
metrics.description: Represents the vertical organization of relationships, measuring how many concepts rely on single-relationship paths.
metrics.interpretation: Higher values indicate that concepts are arranged in a more hierarchical (dependent) manner.

metrics.name: Connectedness
metrics.description: Captures overall interrelation: how many connections exist versus total concepts and relationships.
metrics.interpretation: Higher values indicate more lateral links and greater integration among concepts.

metrics.name: Size
metrics.description: Counts the number of distinct concepts in the cognitive map.
metrics.interpretation: Represents the breadth or domain coverage of the map; more concepts can indicate deeper expertise.

metrics.name: UniformityOfSalience
metrics.description: Standard deviation of salience across relationships in the map.
metrics.interpretation: Indicates how uniformly strong the relationships are. A higher deviation implies some beliefs are held more strongly than others.

metrics.name: ConceptComparison
metrics.description: Captures the similarity or overlap in the set of concepts used across two cognitive maps.
metrics.formula: Uses the proportion of shared concepts relative to the union or intersection of concepts in both maps.
metrics.interpretation: Higher values indicate a more similar conceptual vocabulary across the two maps.

metrics.name: TransformationCost
metrics.description: Measures the minimal number of discrete changes needed to convert one cognitive map into another (additions, deletions, salience changes).
metrics.formula: A Levenshtein-style count of insertions/deletions/adjustments of relationships or concepts.
metrics.interpretation: Higher cost indicates more extensive restructuring of beliefs over time or between different actors.

metrics.name: Incongruence
metrics.description: Captures the difference between two maps while adjusting for shared concepts. Focuses on changes in relationships for overlapping concepts.
metrics.formula: No single closed-form is given; uses transformations among shared concepts only.
metrics.interpretation: Higher values signal greater shifts in underlying beliefs about shared concepts.

steps.objective: Locate subject-relationship-object statements in textual data using content-analysis rules.
steps.completion_criteria: All relevant text is converted into data statements reflecting the speaker's beliefs.

steps.objective: Compile data statements into a semantic network representing concepts, relationships, and conjunctions as unique nodes.
steps.completion_criteria: All extracted statements are merged into a structured network data model.

steps.objective: Consolidate or merge equivalent concept nodes through a synonym facility.
steps.completion_criteria: Any discovered synonyms or near-equivalent references are unified if directed by the analyst.

steps.objective: Calculate structural and comparative metrics (dependency, connectedness, transformation cost, etc.).
steps.completion_criteria: All relevant numerical indicators are produced for subsequent analysis.

steps.objective: Apply process models (e.g., directed-walk) that use the semantic network for simulating belief-driven inferences or decisions.
steps.completion_criteria: Model completes inference generation, producing predicted decisions or outcomes based on the network.

Telos.success_criteria: Captures the structure of an actor’s beliefs in enough detail to allow meaningful structural and process analysis.
